assertions.title: convey the accessible name of the select
assertions.rationale: The user needs to know the purpose of the select.
examples: A screen reader might convey the name as "<role>, <name>, <value>"

assertions.title: convey the select role
assertions.rationale: The user needs to know that the element has select behavior.
examples: A screen reader might convey the select as a select or a combo box

assertions.title: convey changes to the value after making a selection
assertions.rationale: The user needs to know that the value was successfully changed.
examples: A screen reader might announce the new value after it has been changed

assertions.title: convey the current value of the select
assertions.rationale: The user needs to know that the current value is when they navigate to the control.
examples: A screen reader might convey the name as "<role>, <name>, <value>"

assertions.title: convey the boundaries of the options within the select
assertions.rationale: The user needs to know that when they enter and leave the options.
examples: A screen reader might convey the option name when enter thing select, and "out of select" when exiting
A screen reader might convey information about the position in the options, such as "4 of 4" to indicate the start and end of the options

assertions.title: convey the expanded and collapsed states
assertions.rationale: The user might find it helpful to know if the select is open or closed.
examples: A screen reader might convey the collapsed state as "4 of 4" and the expanded state as
A screen reader will usually imply the expanded state by sending focus to the option list. When the user leaves the option list, the select becomes collapsed.

assertions.title: provide shortcuts to jump to text inputs
assertions.rationale: Screen reader users might want to quickly navigate to different text inputs on the page.
examples: A screen reader might provide a keyboard shortcut to jump to the next form control or provide a list of all form controls
